values.comments:
Management 104 focuses on the economic and institutional constraints on organizations in the formulation and implementation of human resources management policies and strategies in the United States and, as appropriate, internationally.  The specific constraints discussed are labor markets (external and internal), labor laws (governing employment policies and employee relations), and labor unions (and the threat thereof).  Particular attention is paid to the relationship of these constraints to the competitiveness of American enterprise in the global economy.

Students felt that they would retain the information learned in this class even after the semester. The course is relevant to those going into "consulting or other industry jobs (other than banking).” Some of the information was closely tied to material taught in MGMT 101 and 238.

Professor Cobb was able to "mold the course around his students" and oftentimes used current events to make examples relevant. He is passionate about the subject matter and very enthusiastic. Some students criticized how opinionated he was, because it made them hold back their political opinions. Students raved about his personality and energy. 

Students said that there were many readings and that the readings were long.

The focus of Management 104 is the economic and institutional constraints on
organizations in the formulation and implementation of human resources management
policies and strategies in the United States and, as appropriate, internationally. The
specific constraints discussed are labor markets (external and internal), labor laws
(governing employment policies and employee relations), and labor unions (and the
threat thereof). Particular attention is paid to the relationship of these constraints to the
competitiveness of American enterprise in the global economy.
Students enjoyed the course and discussions in class.
Professor Cobb was "great at making the material relevant and was very attune to
students' needs and conflicts." He was humorous, engaging, and good at maintaining
interest among students. However, some students felt he tried to "push his political
opinions in class." Some students felt that classes were not a "safe space for discussion,"
especially pointing to an Occupy Wall Street discussion in class.
Students found the slides and lecture material "approachable and easy to understand."
